What if the taller a tree, the more likely a small mammal (such as a squirrel) is able to climb up there and avoid larger predators (such as foxes) that cannot climb trees without low hanging branches. Then these small mammals that are more plentiful can spread more seeds, giving a selective advantage to talk trees.
No low branches also gives room for a whole new niches to appear and live in (readily apparent in rainforests). These new animals can help with nutrients (poop), move seeds, and other beneficial activities.
Further, the tallest of trees, redwoods, require fires to such a great extent to clear the ground of any small brush that would compete with their saplings that their pinecones only open when there are fires. Because redwoods have high branches, they can survive fires (along with other adaptations) that provide a clear evolutionary advantage.

I kinda hate this idea, although it is a good way of enabling you to think about what selective pressures trees are under. There are plenty more reasons for a tree to be tall than sunlight, and I think you would have done well to mention this or maybe do a follow up on this.

For example, if the trees canopies were at ground level then they would be subject to predation by any and every herbivore. One of the selective advantages of being tall is undoubtedly being safe from ground dwelling predators.

There is also the issue of pollination of flowers and spreading of seeds. Different trees have different methods of pollination and spreading of seeds. Insects, bats and birds are commonly used for pollination while some trees use fruit, simple nuts or wind born seeds to spread their seeds. If all trees were short then it is difficult to see how trees which use wind to spread their seeds could flourish. There of obvious other issues for other methods as well, bug clearly it would not benefit all trees equally.

There is also the issue of climate to consider. Fire would be a devastating occurrence in short forest, as all of the highly combustible material (leaves) would be basically surrounding the trunk. This would lead to fires so hot that trees would find it difficult to survive. With the heat right at ground level, it would make it more difficult for seeds to survive a fire as well.

Flooding would be potentially similarly destructive as well, being tall undoubtedly has advantages in areas that flood constantly. Drought may be just as bad, trees which store water in their trunks would only be able to store small amounts in short trunks and so may not be able to survive a prolonged dry period.

Being at ground level would also lead to competition from other types of plants. Grasses, shrubs and the like would be able to compete with trees for water, space and sunlight. Having a tall forest canopy means that only trees can play the forest game. Vines are a common occurrence in forests, but they would be much more common in short forests and thanks to their fast growing nature may be able to completely strangle and crowd out ground level trees within a short space of time.

What about the issue of uneven land? Would a tree whose seed was unlucky enough to fall in a gully be obliged to remain the same height as the tree on the top of the hill? You might say this is fair, but the tree in the gully will have more water it can use to grow taller than the trees higher on the slope, so it is at an indirect disadvantage under this system by being forced to forego the use of resources available to it.

I could go on, but I think that'll do it for now.

One of the most important reasons trees (specifically conifers and angiosperms) grew to be so tall was to facilitate seed dispersal over long distance. If you grow close to the ground like moss (briophyta) the organism has to depend on water to disperse its sperm (mosses don't have seeds). Interestingly enough even bryophytes use hight to their advantage. The sporophyte of a moss is taller then its dominant gametophyte which allows at least a little seed dispersal.

I think mentioning the age of forests would have been nice, particularly as it applies to soil conditions (e.g., soil structure, pH, organic matter). As in, at different periods (e.g., 10 years, 50 years, hundreds of years) different species of trees tend to dominate the grove. Early in the age of a "forest" the trees dominating the area has less to do with light penetration and more to do with soil conditions and surrounding animals. As the forest matures the soil conditions change to better host other species of trees. Another reason for bare trunks is that certain species of trees become better at avoiding being eaten lower towards the ground (e.g. by deer), thus bare trunks.

This is exactly the same reason price collusion can't work in a free market.  The moment one business cuts its prices (even slightly), it will begin to steal market share from the other businesses and they'll be forced to also cut their prices.

This is a very interesting point. In economics we found this same result in enterprises. If several firms collude in order to have prices higher than they usually would (a cartel), every firm has an incentive to lower their prices and then all the other firms would follow that firm and get their prices lower. This is a very classic example used in game theory.

This is NOT why socialism, communism, capitalism, feudalism, etc., etc. fail. Each of these systems can and do have laws that either increase the cost of growing taller or decrease the cost of remaining short to protect the forest/economy. This made me think (which is why I subscribe) about evolution of different organisms in regards to cooperation and competition.  Trees and humans are singular entities (ignoring the parasites and symbiotic internal partners) that have an evolutionary ability and imperative to pass on our distinctive genes, and so the kind of unconsciously individual self-sacrificial behavior like limiting ones height or standing back from the baggage carousel unlikely to evolve.  However, other organisms don't have unique genes or don't have an ability to pass them on, like most members of bee and ant colonies.  Their very existence is more like a cell of a larger organism.  The colony as a whole can better continue its genetic line by each individual ignoring their own individual interest.  Almost like cells or organs within our bodies, like white blood cells sacrificing themselves to ensure the survival of the body.  I would guess that 2 worker ants from the same colony would never compete with each other because there's no evolutionary purpose to it.

This explains a lot that I haven't thought about much before, and explains why communism can't work.  It's in our genes to seek an advantage over our fellow tree.

will have to disagree with the way analogy is presented. The reason we behave like jerks at the airport is that because we have different constrains at the point of disembarking the aircraft. Some people are desperate to catch a bus, because the next one is like 2 hours later, some have a parking ticket that is about to expire, and even 30 sec can make a difference whether you get away with a modest fee or will have to incur a ridiculous charge. Also you may be tired from the long flight, and keeping yourself 'jerking' is a way of stretching muscles and pushing blood around. The same is with tree ecology. Even if you agree not to grow tall, you will have individuals in a disadvantageous position, like e.g. if you have a huge boulder underneath your root system and hence you can't get enough water and nutrients, and you will claim everyone around is cheating by growing taller. Alternatively, you may hit a lucky spot, and despite you've signed up for a 'friendship' deal, you can't really help yourself growing bigger. So the reason is that small variations in the initial conditions may result in large variation in outcome, which is effectively the definition of instability.

Trees will put out shoots on the lower trunk when light becomes available. If you cut down all the trees around one of those in the next couple years it would put out a bunch of shoots on the trunk, some of which would die and some of which would become full branches. That's why you see "wolf" trees in open fields with lots of branches really close to the ground and a relatively short main trunk. They grow towards the light and try to get as much as possible. They do do whats in their own best interest. That said many trees have different strategies.

For example, oaks tend to invest heavily in their roots early in life to try to get plenty of nutrients. As a result they have less stem growth and tend to be shorter than, say, cottonwood of the same age which invests heavily in stem growth. The oaks have evolved this strategy to out compete other species for nutrients and endure lower light conditions. Cottonwood has evolved to get above all other plants around it as quickly as possible and under stress will invest even more heavily in stem growth. Sugar maple is different from them both. It just sits there as a tiny sapling, waiting for some disturbance to open the overstory, sometimes for over a hundred years. Then when the overstory does open it grows to fill the gap. Black walnut is theorized to exhibit allelopathy, where it releases chemicals into the soil to kill off other plants. Some trees live their entire life in the understory, shaded by the trees above.

Different organisms have different strategies for survival. I can appreciate what you're trying to say but maybe choose a simpler metaphor. Or don't oversimplify what's happening.

You were saying putting energy into the canopy is where it makes the most sense. I agree to some degree but putting energy into the trunk is equally important as it ensures new functional water conducting pipes (xylem) every year. When you look at a cross section of a tree trunk, you can find heartwood (dysfunctional xylem) and sapwood (functional xylem). The functional pipes are usually restricted to the outermost growth rings! In order to be able to stick around for hundreds of years trees need to have functional pipes which come in form of subsequent growth in diameter. Now one can ask what evolved first: 1) growth in diameter (which, besides making more xylem to ensure water transport over hundreds of years, also provide a foundation for additional height growth so that trees won't break) OR 2) height growth came first which needed support so that trees won't break and as a useful byproduct also produced functional pipes. Any thoughts? But I do enjoy your videos :) Keep up the good work!

What you're describing sounds a lot like the prisoner's dilemma: If two prisoners cooperate during interrogation and refuse to testify against each other, they each get 1 year of jail time.  If one betrays the other (or in the case of trees, grows taller), that individual goes free but the other gets 3 years of jail time.  If they both betray each other, they both get 2 years of jail time.  As such, the outcome that seems the most rational (betray your accomplice to try to get out of serving any time) yields a worse result than the choice that seems irrational (since cooperating with the other prisoner guarantees at least 1 year of jail time).

The logic you use here @Veritasium is identical to that used in the Bertrand's model of perfect competition (in economics). The general gist is that firms set the price for their products, and consumers will buy from the cheapest seller. While it would be more advantageous for multiple firms to collude (aka fixing the price) and all choose to charge the same, high price, so they all receive the same high profits, any one firm could charge just a little bit less (undercut) the other firms, and steal the entire market of consumers. Eventually, the theory goes that each firm will continue to undercut the others until each firm is charging a price where MC = MR (marginal cost and marginal revenue; aka where the cost of making 1 more unit of product is equal to the revenue of selling 1 more unit of product, aka the price of the product).

this is basically like game theory and the Nash Equilibrium where if, for example, 2 firms acting like one monopoly split the quantity of output, they will both maximize profit and output, but if one firm cheats and decides to produce more than what they agreed on it will increase it's output and profit while the other firm will lose profit and have a decrease in output, so the second firm will also decide to produce more, but now since supply has increased prices will go down which will eventually lead to a Nash Equilibrium and lower profits for both firms compared to when they had an agreement (pareto optimal).

Yes! I got the airport analogy right away! I think about this chain reaction with an unstable solution all the time. It is the same reason that a classroom full of noisy kids get louder and louder, they need to speak louder to trump the loud kids, who need to speak even louder.

The same thing occurs in Economics (we call it the prisoners dilemma). The stable solution will outcome if both parties develop a strategy which is a possible reaction to the otyer party's strategy.

For example:
One tree is wondering if he should grow tall or short. He starts thinking what the best strategy will be as a reaction to what the other trees do. If the other trees grow short, it's the most beneficial for you if you grow tall, if the other trees grow tall, it's also the most beneficial for you if you grow tall. So whatever the other trees do, you would be better of growing tall. This goes for all the trees in the forest, so they all grow tall.

The dilemma is that this solution isn't the best one, because it's more beneficial for every tree when they are all short then when they are all tall.

This solution will occur when you start making pacts/trust/friendship.

Hope this gave you all a different look at this problem :)!

This is a Nash Equilibrium, which is not a Pareto-efficient solution., this is also called '' The Market failure''. You see economics is all around us, in this case game theory. This solution is unstable because people or gamers always tries to maximize the profit.

There's another, evolutionary factor -- it's not all about cooperative living. The most efficient organisms are those that can compete at the highest level, so the species that can promote reproduction of the most fit organisms stands more likely to survive. As artificial as it may seem, having a competition for growth rate with the reward of reproduction promotes evolution towards the most fit germ line. Without competition within the species, the door opens for other species to find a way to exploit weakness. In a way, being tall is just an abstract marker, like fancy feathers, that hints to underlying efficiency.
